# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Integer=3)
    if !(isa(bump, Integer)) || bump < 0
        throw(ArgumentError("`bump` must be a positive integer"))
    end
    return DateTime(year(dt), month(dt), day(dt), hour(dt) + bump, minute(dt), second(dt), millisecond(dt))
end
```

This function checks that `bump` is a positive integer and then creates a new `DateTime` object by adding the specified number of hours to the original timestamp. If no `bump` value is provided, it defaults to +3 hours. The function works only with `DateTime` types and will throw an `ArgumentError` if you try to use a `Date` type.
